description.en:
Individual work with the literature of the given research field, following a list/plan agreed with the lecturer. The time of the exam will be negotiated with the lecturer responsible.
This is not a 'fact-oriented' exam, where students are tested to see if they can recite what author X said in chapter 3 or author Y in article 4. Rather, it's about demonstrating a level of maturity concerning the field and being able to compare and synthesize material in a free and open intellectual exchange. Students should view the exam as a way of establishing for themselves a lasting feeling of familiarity with their discipline, as well as an opportunity to strategically develop different scholarly profiles, which will help them both in their dissertation work as well as future teaching activities. This is the chance to master important aspects of the field in order to prepare oneself both for research and a professional career.

objectives.en: The aim of the course is to help a PhD student obtain deep theoretical and empirical knowledge relevant for their PhD dissertation in the field of governance and digital transformation. At the same time, the course can serve as a partial preparation for potential teaching opportunities in the same field.

independent_work.et:
The exam is based on self-study. There are no formal seminars or classes meant to prepare for the exam. However, in addition to independent reading and reflection, students are also highly encouraged:
(a) to audit (where relevant) MA-level courses that cover the same literature; this will provide you with a structured context for engaging the literature and discussing thoughts with others;
(b) to form study groups with other doctoral students when preparing for the actual exam. If you plan to take the exam during a certain semester, contact your fellow doctoral colleagues at least two months in advance about perhaps forming a study group, and then draw up a schedule of meetings (preferably weekly).

All the required literature is numerically listed and should be generally available through University of Tartu library or its subscriptions. Should there be trouble in accessing the literature then please contact the faculty. 

The exam is composed of two parts. 

- The first part is dedicated to the general topic of governance and its digital transformation. 
- Second, the student must prepare knowledge of at least two countries (other than Estonia) in order to demonstrate an ability to apply theories and concepts in an empirical context. Students can choose themselves the relevant country material they wish to use. 

The format of the exam is oral. The student is given five questions, from which he/she must choose two. The student has up to 60 minutes to prepare in relation to each question a 20-minute presentation. During the presentation the student must bring in the relevant theoretical literature as well as examples drawn from his/her chosen countries. After the presentation, the exam committee may ask for clarifications or pose other questions. Generally the exam lasts up to 60 minutes. The exam is pass/fail.

description.et: The examinee is expected to demonstrate 1) a thorough understanding of the most important theoretical debates and key texts of the general topic of governance and digital transformation; 2) an ability to apply theories and concepts in an empirical context to the cases of at least two countries (other than Estonia).
